awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Distributed Predictive Control of Cold Atmospheric Microplasma Jet Arrays for Materials Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Cold atmospheric plasmas are composed of weakly ionized gases containing a mixture of ions, electrons, neutral and excited species, and photons at relatively low temperatures. Cold atmospheric plasmas are emerging as an effective and cheaper alternative to the low-pressure plasma technology and are increasingly used in materials processing and manufacturing applications. In these applications there has been a growing interest in using arrays of microplasma jets to scale up the surface area treated by plasma. This project is focused on addressing challenges involved in the control of such microplasma jets. This research will lead to the development of new models and advanced model-based controllers for plasma jet arrays opening new vistas in other areas such as plasma medicine and biomedical engineering. The outcomes of this work will advance research in data-driven modeling and distributed control of nonlinear distributed-parameter systems with interacting subsystems. The educational and outreach activities planned in this effort are natural extensions of this multidisciplinary research.

The overarching goal of this collaborative research between University of California at Berkeley and University of Georgia is to develop a systems theoretic framework for tractable modeling and optimal control of plasma jet arrays for state-of-the-art materials processing applications that critically hinge on uniform treatment of large surface areas. This goal will be realized through fusion of nonlinear systems theory for data-driven modeling of distributed-parameter systems and distributed model predictive control. The key objectives of the project are to: (1) develop a novel framework for non-parametric, input-output modeling of nonlinear distributed-parameter systems; (2) develop a distributed control approach that can systematically coordinate predictive control of spatially distributed but interacting systems; and (3) test the modeling and distributed control methods for effective and reproducible operation of a micro-plasma jet array consisting of several jets through real-time control experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cold atmospheric plasmas (CAPs) are composed of a weakly ionized gas containing a mixture of ions, electrons, neutral and excited species, and photons at relatively low temperatures. CAPs are emerging as an effective and cheaper alternative to the low-pressure plasma technology (e.g., widely used in semiconductor manufacturing) due to the ability to achieve enhanced gas-phase chemistry without the need for elevated gas temperatures. In particular, this attractive characteristic has led to the increasing use of CAPs in materials processing and manufacturing applications that require a low processing temperature. Examples include surface treatment and modification of high-performance materials (e.g., heat-sensitive polymers or biomaterials), thin-film synthesis (e.g., deposition of silicon dioxide films on semiconductor wafers), and treatment of porous materials for energy harvesting and storage devices. However, reproducible and effective operation of CAP discharges is particularly challenging due to the intrinsic variability and complex nature of plasma dynamics and plasma effects on the target surface, as well as strong sensitivity to disturbances from environment. For example, electrical properties and coupled transport and chemical phenomena in plasma can vary considerably from run to run under nearly identical operating conditions, posing a significant challenge to consistency and reproducibility of plasma treatment of materials.

 

This project focused on developing a systems theoretic framework for learning-based modeling and control of a particular class of CAP discharges, namely atmospheric pressure plasma jets, to enable their high-performance operation in materials processing and manufacturing applications. The developed framework drew on data-driven model learning, probabilistic uncertainty quantification using Bayesian machine learning methods, and stochastic model predictive control techniques that can systematically account for probabilistic system uncertainty in control. In addition, the developed systems theoretic framework and methods in this project were experimentally tested on an atmospheric pressure plasma system with prototypical applications in (bio)materials processing. The major outcome of the project was to demonstrate how learning-based control strategies that simultaneously learn and control the complex dynamics of plasmas could potentially transform the current practice of operating cold atmospheric plasma devices in materials processing applications, which is mainly based on open-loop control strategies. The findings of this project can be potentially applied to a wide range of engineering systems, in which predictive control in an uncertain and hard-to-model environment is essential. The scientific outcomes of this project included several publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings, as well as several presentations in national and international meetings. Last but not least, the project facilitated training of graduate students in multidisciplinary scholarly research.
